page.title: 07Whipping Tops
page.content: During breaktimes at Garway School some children play with whips and tops. The whips are made of lengths of dowelling with thongs of leather attached to them. The top is round and tapers to a metal tip. At the thick end there is a groove into which the leather of the whip is wound. When the whip is given a sharp tug the leather unwinds and the top starts to spin. If you have pulled hard enough then the top should keep spinning for a long time. When it starts to slow down you whip it to keep it going. If you whip it the wrong way it just stops. Joanna's grandfather made the tops for us. At the school fete this year Richard ran a sideshow to see who could keep the top spinning for the longest time.
